be1zim4HAiy0VnUN5uSISw.text: Without a shadow of a doubt the best pizza I've had this side of Naples. Usually have to wait for a table as this is a tiny neighbourhood place. Recommend the take-away option for anyone without the patience to wait your turn.

glQ1S9DaiqZGyZBhxCuxmA.text: Love this pizza joint next door to the pub in a tiny place-. Weekend evenings its a madhouse. Pizza is A 1 and too would recommend take out.

5MV-TcmGATaZh2FxkVAgQw.text: It's busy here for a good reason. Awesome pizza. Fantastic hosts. Love it!

I0b7jk4HQNUM82ttHKMAbA.text: Terrible service, arrogant and way below the standard you should expect. This place has always been cramped and slightly unfriendly and they seem to think that the 2010 Time Out award makes them untouchable. I've been eating here since it opened and I'd have given them 4 stars back then but I can honestly say that the staff, but more importantly the pizza are nowhere near as good as they used to be. It's a shame but there are other places to get great pizza in Ealing that are not so cramped, are no more expensive and have a service level that puts Santa Maria to shame.

TLmqcMDO28ik9WeWOXW_cw.text: It may be the best pizza in London - I haven't had a lot of pizza in the city. I can say it's not even close to the best pizza I've ever had. The tiny location means leisurely enjoying your food is all but impossible. Service went from brisk to brusque within about 10 minutes of our pizzas being served. And while I do love wood fired pizza, the center was incredibly soggy. I would say hold off till you can either get to Naples, or NYC. ;)

LAbk-Augiul_qTPByK16aQ.text: An ancient proverb says see Naples, then you die...which means the city is (or at least was) so beautiful than you don't need to see anything else. Well...the same applies to Pizzeria Santa Maria, which is by far the best Neapolitan Pizza in London! For those who appreciate a cosy environment, where the freshness of the ingredients and the attention to details (i.e. the temperature of the oven, cooking time, the softness of the dough) is paramount, this is the place to be. For those who don't, and probably don't even know the difference between fiordilatte and buffalo mozzarella, well...go to Pizza Express!? :)As a genuine Neapolitan and a great pizza fan, I can tell with no doubts this is the closer to perfection you can get, outside Napoli.

kyfq4dCnFs2fJXrgrq5Crw.text: Pizza was excellent. Salad was fresh. (House) Wine was reasonably priced. Service was pretty good. Very small place, but definitely worth a visit or take away

DM_qq4u5AfjXT_iq4U0_tg.text: Instead of jumping on a flight to Napoli to get the only real pizza on the planet, you can now easily take the Tube to Ealing! The pizza here is expertly prepared in a roaring brick oven, playing front and centre in the kitchen, with traditional Neapolitan ingredients from the light and fluffy dough (but only for the crust, the rest is thin thin and not crisp in the middle  that's how its supposed to be) to the San Marzano tomatoes, olive oil and the fior di latte d.o.c. The Santa Maria guys know what good pizza tastes like because they grew up with it and they're making sure that Londoners now can too. The décor is clean and simple, with art and photos evoking Napoli and a super stylised depiction of a venerated Madonna icon (the Santa Maria di Merino from Vieste, a village near Napoli). Service is warm, friendly and very welcoming. Get here early if you want a table or opt for take-away in one of their cool customised pizza boxes. The prices are excellent with a margherita setting you back under £6.

VNzcUoSUMixYVmbFZDSGmA.text: Cramped interior, can't book, always a queue  who cares, the food is amazing. I have never had better pizzas in the UK, the one with spicy sausage and chilli (Santa Carmela?) is just so good. Service is really friendly, even when I take my 3 year old daughter in, nothing is a problem and all of the staff talk to my daughter, rather than look annoyed that we have brought a small child. If you are still hungry after the pizza, have the pistacchio ice cream, just the thing to finish.

JDCegUL4xu5hvyzTSfuphQ.text: Unpleasant and cramped venue, you'll be almost rubbing shoulders with another table. The staff's attitude is arrogant and indifferent and the pizza on our visit was soggy as if either their oven is faulty or they don't know what they're doing. Either way hardly deserving of some of the comments here. Plenty of decent places to eat in Ealing but I won't be going to this one again in a hurry.

o_O0E0vDIdfacR_fijX17w.text: Excellent place. Inexpensive, good atmosphere and the best pizza I have had in the UK.

eBn7YaX8viK_Qln7RX8u8w.text: Is this worth a trek across London?Yes.I left feeling uncomfortably full yet wanting more. That's a good thing. We wanted a table for two and arrived about 6:30pm on a Wednesday and were seated right away. Pizza arrived quickly and was really delicious. I highly recommend the Funghi-- the fragrance was really incredible. I wish I had something really nuanced or witty to say about this place, but I don't. It is just really good Italian pizza. Wish I lived closer. Ok, not really, but I wish they would open a branch closer to ME. There. That's more accurate. Fab pizza for under a tenner.

NMnGq6J0PSTKqzZ-IepsQw.text: if your in the area you cant go wrong with Santa Maria Pizzeria.  I've had many excellent pizzas in NYC during my time living there, and whilst SMP is not up there with the best its still delicious.  the crust has a great balance but was much softer  than the classic NYC coal fired oven pizza. however, wash it down with their tasty house wine at £10 a carafe  and its an afternoon well spent!

5RHA93GX8JK6L5RHeDKeZw.text: This restaurant may be small but it simply gives a boutique intimate feel to this delicious pizza. It definitely rivals authentic Italian pizza and it's priced extremely well so I would recommend this as a must go place for any pizza lover. Make reservations though!

l_MYh6FYZny25X9hhiFuug.text: You know how everyone in London says their area has the best pizza? Well they are wrong. Because this is absolutley hands down the best. I had the San Mattina which is primarily Mozzarella and truffle oil! It was the beautiful kind of thin based pizza that you get in Naples that just wraps around your fork. If there was a bottle of Lambrusco on the table I probably would have believed I actually was in Naples and not Ealing Broadway. The range of desserts was small, no fuss Italian staples such as gelato and tiramisu, but made up for it by being delicious. The staff were friendly and engaging going around singing and chatting to the customers. These people clearly love what they do and are very good at it. This is one of those places that makes you happy you moved to West London. Well worth the trip out. We have vowed to make it a regular excursion.

-JbwCMuT2wxE8bK44F5urA.text: Do you want eat a real Neapolitan pizza?.....just go there its the best pizza i ever had in long time.Great little place and great atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Great place.....

HMClwLPECkBWWuygxK70PA.text: Love this place, just wish it was a little bigger with more areas to sit. Because of this we only ever get take-away from here.The pizzas are really good, although sometimes too soggy in the middle. Before you all yell "they're supposed to be that way" I know. I mean they are too soggy (sometimes) even for this style of pizza.However, this does not prevent me from ordering again and again because they really are good pizzas.The Bruschetta is also very good. If only they had more seats...

6dN6-0OI-M1eWWsW1BGStw.text: Quite a small place without reservations. In busy days you have to wait a while to be seated. The pizza is awesome thou.

Cyzwi29vrfScj9P4vabGUQ.text: What else can you say about the best pizza restaurant in London! Simple and with excellent ingredients, perfect!

ksgXg-iEt-C2xB27e0enNQ.text: Real deal!! Real Neapolitan style!! Pizza is how it has to be.. With a little thick edge and a "melt in your mouth dough" is the perfect combination, not chewy just delicious.. Oven high temperature allows pizza to get cooked in less than 2 minutes meaning the dough has the right softness and texture. Don't worry if it's busy, just take your pizza away and have it on the street!

BpwITxQE-5VINvXyupjZkg.text: Am an absolute fan! Lovely thin pizza with just enough toppings! Really friendly staff and brilliant materials.

L4xLgZ8XoPhbUyfxSirI2w.text: The real deal ... and the next best thing to having pizza in Naples. Delicious pizzas from a wood fired oven with a perfect salsa that's not too sweet, very reasonably priced between £4.50 and £7.95 and served with an appreciative smile in a cosy and invited little restaurant. If Ealing's a bit out of the way, well, suck it up and go anyway (it's a short walk from the Tube station). This is a wonderful pizzeria. Grazie!

gt_n8YWY3aVI4qg5Jh21uA.text: Most delicious pizzas I've ever had in London, and at an excellent price!I'd recommend either the Catalina (salami) or Danielle (parma ham) though I'm sure the others are just as delicious.You can take out as well. Which is great when you're working evenings just down the road. They take less than 5 minutes to prepare more often.

1oOIwY8RUKvTsREC0MSPhg.text: My friend celebrated her 30th birthday at this restaurant and it was full of family and friends. The atmosphere was incredible but some of the staff were quite rude and ruined the birthday party

o0mhXvPqmgTSNYj-uJDUvw.text: Great authentic rustic pizza made really quickly right in front of you. The pizza I had was a really fine mix of cheeses, lots of garlic and good quality mushrooms. The crust is so incredible you will want to eat every bit of it. Do stay for espresso and tiramisu. Both are excellent. The restaurant is tiny, so you might have to time your visit to get a table. Service was efficient and friendly. All the staff I saw were Italian. Five stars!

QaQISVfKEHnKhLyTQC34YQ.text: Best pizza in London. Fresh and crispy. Never tasted anything like it. Will be going back soon.

6plfjM73SpUJMctSo5Lm3w.text: Santa Maria Pizzeria has some of the best crust, fastest service, and an over all good feeling. Nice people. Recommended!    I had the Santa Carmela per the waitress' recommendation and it was good. My girlfriend had the Margarita and it needed a little bit more basil to add to its finesse.

uQdaJ5anIitXE-Zz5jn-Rw.text: I went in there with my fella last Monday, after a friend suggested the place and we were both amazed to eat such a delicious pizza!The dough is soft and light, accordingly to the authentic Neapolitan recipe, the tomato sauce is luscious and succulent and toppings are fresh and obviously carefully sourced from Italy What else can I say??? Maybe that the staff is friendly and helpful and the ambience feels homely and cosy??? No wonder Santa Maria was buzzy on a cold Monday night after only two or three weeks from the opening

dJQA7LhjOprq9pJleIQqsA.text: There are the italian pizza and other kind of pizza around the world. This is a proper neapolitan pizza (yes, there are also so many different kinds of italian pizza). If you have tasted one, fell in love for it and don't have plans to go to Naples this is the place to go. And if you haven't tried yet this is definitely the place to go (and fall in love for it). The place is small, and cosy, the price is fair, the recipe is traditional and the flavour is wonderful. So wonderful that worth the travel (I live in the opposite side of London).

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

snK3Mnb4GXEYZAlzhieepg.text: Wow! Seriously good pizza and seriously nice owners. Best pizza I've had in London yet!

iKekbzWCZzU4CzRib_wAsg.text: Had the truffle and buffalo  mozzarella pizza really delicious . The service was friendly and quick pity there isn't more seating as it's usually busy and you will have about of a wait. I will return to try a different pizza soon.

HCKSsuucMKDR01NxwUOS_Q.text: Best pizza in London. Possibly the best meal I've consumed in London in the two years I have lived here. The restaurant is very small with a few tables in the front, a few tables in the back, and two tables on the pavement. They don't take reservations, so if you want to ensure a table without a wait, go at off-peak times (although I'm not sure this restaurant is ever empty!).

xbrfiHClIYaFeRwipf0FsQ.text: Excellent pizza! As pizza is the only item on the menu, you expect them to do it well... and they do!The ingredients on the pizza were fresh and I would happily eat the parma ham from the San Daniele all day. We also got the Santa Ana and the artichokes were cooked perfectly. The best is the crust. A gorgeously thin crust, full of flavour and a nice hint of wood smoke from the brick ovens. The service was very friendly and the restaurant was cosy and intimate.

tE-OzGKzNzqzlqAhhC8cqQ.text: Wow yum yum, this is the best pizza I've had in London. It Still doesn't beat Lombardi's in New York for me but it comes a close second.This restaurant is teeny tiny inside, theres prob  max of 10 tables, The restaurant has a really nice vibe, the guys were singing in Italian as the sun shone outside.The pizzas are very thin and soggy but thats the way I like it, I got the Santa Bufalina and it was delicious! The service wasn't amazing at the restaurant but I didn't find them rude or unfriendly and will definitely be going back. I can't believe it took me so long to visit

1OOBtcf4w3jfX60uSSH7sg.text: The pizzas, albeit once fine, are now occasionally acceptable; the service remains lamentably arrogant. The venue suffers.

it7teJNyTG_RTLsTVfzN3A.text: Best pizza Ive ever had, super fresh ingredients. Traditional italian. Long wait, as expected for really great food. Honest prices. The bruschetta as a starter is amazing as well.

xJNb6jMEdTJX6LPS_POXrA.text: As sure as you can be after eating one pizza (and a couple of starters), this place is worth the hype. A tiny little restaurant that doesn't take reservations so can be hard to get seated at peak times. Lots of choice in the menu but all pizzas are kept fairly simple and not overtopped like most takeaways pizza. At 9.95 a pizza, it's a pretty good deal for definitely one of the best pizzas in London.

vfPvkL2RdmL7_0M71F2zRw.text: Santa Maria Pizzeria has long been on my list of pizza joints to try - especially after making the news first for tossing out a couple of girls looking for just a salad (standard.co.uk/news/orde…) and then again when TimeOut and Evening Standard named it the best pizza in London. Santa Maria bills itself as an authentic Neapolitan pizzeria and, with ingredients flown in from Italy, it seems to be just that. The small 16 cover spot usually commands waits of over an hour (it does offer takeaway as an option) and cultivates a cosy café atmosphere. While it ticks all the boxes for authentic pizza, is it worthy of the best pizza in London? Nope, not for me, as the low prices weren't enough to make up for the relatively plain pizza. I'd prefer to pay a little extra and get a pie from Homeslice or Pizza Lupo.The key thing to note when choosing your pizza is the type of sauce. We opted for a Sant'Anna (a tomato-sauce based pizza) and the San Daniele (a sauce-less pie drizzled with olive oil instead) and there was a marked difference in the taste and experience. The San Daniele was generously topped with parma ham, wild rocket, and shavings of parmesan cheese on a soft pizza base which lends itself to being folded for easy eating. The bold flavours of the ingredients complemented each other although the halved cherry tomatoes seemed a bit of an odd add-on as they didn't stay on the pizza and turned into more of a side dish.In comparison, the Sant'Anna turned into a soggy mess of carbs and flavourless tomato sauce topped with julienned ham. Basically it was a mess to eat and any flavour from the ingredients seemed washed out. A little bit of Google searching later than night resulted in strong recommendations against takeaway for sauce based Neapolitan pizza as the thin pizza wilts quickly in the steamy conditions created by a takeaway box. It would have been nice if Santa Maria had at least warned us about the risk.For £10.95, the San Daniele was a good value option that I'd be happy to go for again. It didn't knock my socks off, but I'd happily have it for a takeaway dinner. The Sant'Anna at £8.95 seemed like a good deal but for takeaway it failed miserably and I'd have been happier with a Tesco sandwich. The tiramisu at £4.25 seemed strangely expensive given the low priced menu and I wouldn't have bothered in hindsight.

RnMfeWUz8zxADcYNG_6scQ.text: Absolutely AMAZING! The best crust I've had outside of Italy. Chewy, flavorful, perfectly baked in a brick oven. You will not want to leave a single crumb! Voted best pizza in London last year by Time Out, I would be shocked to find a better pizza here. Run by Italians, frequented by more Italians. And like in Italy, pizza served with knife and fork. I discovered it Sunday, went back on Tuesday, and again on Friday. I had to put my food down and say not to a request to go there today for fear I'd turn into a pizza. Pretty sure I gained a pound a day last week and so worth it!!The garlic cheese focaccia is excellent, be warned, it's practically a pizza. The aubergine starter, delish. The bruschetta, delish. The tiramisu, do I need to repeat myself? The prices reasonable for the quality and portions. If you were in Italy you'd pay less, but you're in London.The service excellent all 3 times, friendly and prompt. They are pretty serious about their seating but don't believe the pizza nazi hype. Just order a damn pizza and you won't have a problem. If you don't order a pizza you deserve to be scolded!Who knew this very very West suburb of London would be swimming in great restaurants! Lucky me :) Do yourself a favor, pay Ealing a visit and enjoy a pie, you will forget how far you came and wonder why you waited so long.

OlpnZnoxFfjgDrJBcVvj5Q.text: To me, it was just average at best. The tomato sauce was quite watery and there was nothing exceptional about the pizza. Perhaps I went at the wrong time (noon on Monday), but the flavors were quite bland. I understand that Neapolitan pizza is supposed to be simple, and I have had some great Neapolitan pizza, but this pizza was not simple, it was bland.

xcg-zsisAfJ2qYjvOdaZFw.text: Amazing Pizza, unfortunate seating arrangement.Although I love the pizzas they serve, I can't figure out why they cant get a bigger place. I'm tired of having to squeeze into 2 square feet of space or having to share narrow benches with strangers.The space squeeze is the only reason I'm not 5 starring this joint. That & the fact that I once found a large but delicious fly in my Pizza (to their credit - they replaced the pizza free of charge).

uqxELBAPx4u8EzSROCM6-w.text: An unsuspecting joint with a handful of tables run by Italian hipsters in West London. Easy to dismiss, but don't. Drop in for a pizza and a Peroni and get to know what's arguably one of the best pizzas you'll probably ever eat outside of Italy.In size, they are probably what the chains would consider small but the light, hand-tossed dough makes it easy to devour one by yourself. You can't go wrong with any of the flavor combinations, but just be sure you wash it down with a Peroni (and not the light one, the one in the brown bottle!)

Zuy5gkxxckOWo5zK0olQOQ.text: Way out west in Ealing on St.Mary's is Santa Maria Pizzeria (get the name?). It's the ickle little pizza joint that has the whole of London talking. Time Out's best pizza for 2010? This I had to try.Santa Maria is a pretty place, in a nice part of Ealing with room for about 12 or 14 diners inside and another 8 or so on street tables. Being crowned TO's best pizza means you will often see a queue on the street, and while we were lucky enough to be seated first time, we were hearing other people being told to come back in an hour. Fortunately there's a nice pub next door.So the big question is - how does Santa Maria stack-up against the old London No.1, Franco Manca? Well, in terms of digs - Santa Maria's is much smaller but prettier than FM's Chiswick flagship. Their house wine by the carafe is much better and damn cheap too. Plus they have gorgeous Gelato from Oddonos. But the pizza. THE PIZZA. Oh yes, it's gorgeous, Italian and authentic. A million miles above most London pizzas. But sorry, Franco Manca's still better. It's their sourdough that wins it for FM - just makes the base unstoppably addictive. Plus Santa Maria don't do a capers, olives and anchovy pizza - why not? It's a classic!So Santa Maria: almost as good pizza as Franco Manca, better wine and cuter digs. So close to as good as it gets, and bloody hard to get a table.But not the best pizza in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

AhHt7kaxgQdNRBWfF2-FXg.text: I'm italian and I can strongly say that here I had one of the best pizza ever. Great ingredients, perfect dough, friendly team. I'll definitely eat in this restaurant again soon.

EvvgGsdG48DNJ-zHRkdjtw.text: I loved the Pizza! Loved it. Then you check the price and you love it even more. Have to agree, it's the best in London. Staff were friendly and wait time at 12:00 on a Saturday was only 5 mins. Disappointed we got sat in the back room, but hey ho. Recommend the truffle and mushroom pizza, was fantastic.

dx2Vd0LRtkit89b5kKHg8A.text: A perfect place if you are interested in a very good pizza (italian style).The place is small and you cannot book... and not central at all... but is worth the trip!!

uGdPW45pbPUaKF55inSRug.text: Hands down the best pizzeria London!During my quest to find the best pizza in London, I have tried my fair share of pizzas and I can honestly say that this is the pizzeria this city has to offer. My sniff test is always to try their margheritas.... you know a place is good when their margheritas are simply mouth-wateringly delicious! The only downside for me is the location. I live in central London so making that lengthy trip to Ealing doesn't come easy for me. But if you are craving for authentic Naples style pizzas then this is the number one place to go to!

3T04TZ1zcXRCTP82NgJogQ.text: Best pizza in London, not too expensive and the ice cream is great too. Will not disapoint!

DBMfG_ziQI_Te8oJCLoE2Q.text: Joint best pizza in London, along with Homeslice. Simple and delicious. The base is doughy and chewy and amazing.

WpBLj36UFeWCnwdokZ3Ntw.text: It is truly a perfect placeto all pizza lovers. They offer lots of different Italian pizzas that you canchoose from. They also have a vegetarianpizza for all vegan and health conscious. It is the best crust that I ever tasted. Gorgeouslythin crust that is full of flavour and a nice touch of wood smoke that camefrom the brick ovens.

l2Rq66fsF4DzbgJeePecpA.text: When I heard that Santa Maria Pizzeria was named as London's best pizza by Time Out, I knew I had to try it. But...Ealing? So far.Fortunately, I finally got my chance. And I was impressed. Having lived in Italy, I often find myself disappointed by pizza abroad, as it can never compare to pizza in Italy. I avoid Italian food outside of Italy in general.Santa Maria, is however, different. It's truly what I would call an authentic restaurant. Amazing pizza, homey feel, nice owners. This place is definitely worth travelling to Ealing for.

wPSKnO1x4U28_ExNyeo_-w.text: Best pizza in London! Don't miss, whether you are near Oxford Street or Ealing it is a perfect choice. The dough, the ingredients. Truly Neapolitan pizza!

hMk1inQtA3GcG8ebyqmGwQ.text: Note: I went to the Fitzrovia location, but since there's no page for that location, I'm writing my review here. The manager at the Gucci store in Piccadilly recommended this place (he's from Milan so he knows what real, authentic pizza is). I'm glad he did. We were promptly seated and our waitress was excellent. We started with the Garlic Mozzarella Focaccia, which had the right amount of cheese and wasn't too garlicky. I ordered the Santa Rosa pizza, which had great texture and flavor. If I ever come back to London, I'm eating here again.

X0jnJwZnsnGTGhHQ3hVflQ.text: Very good pizza and this is coming from a snobby NYer. The base is thin like NY pizza. The taste is great: fresh ingredients and a healthy serving of them to boost. I got the San Francisco and was pleased with the amount of veg/sauce/cheese. My only issue is the crust can get very soggy with all the toppings so best to eat or freeze quickly. The Italian staff were very nice whilst I waited for my takeaway pizza.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. San Francisco pizza
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

t8V76JzaDUmycWLfT8orsg.text: I had read that this was the best pizza in Ealing, or maybe even London, and that the ingredients are flown in from Italy. I think everyone who works here is from Italy too, maybe??? Is it the best pizza I have ever had? No.Is it as good as pizza in Italy/ Naples? Eh, maybe.Have I been here more than once? Yes.Have I eaten everything? Also yes.It's a really small space. But it fits a fair amount of people. It's easy to do takeaway, although you can't get some mozzarella dish if you do takeaway.There's a fair amount of variety. Everything is fresh. The pizza has the right consistency/chewiness. I liked it, but I didn't LOVE it as much as I had hoped I would.

RARV4cuCEaNqQWqf2iwT-Q.text: I must admit it's been a long time since I've been here, but here are my thoughts. When we arrived the place was packed, so we sat outside. The staff were clearly not in a good mood and didn't seem all that happy we showed up. Ordering and the service in general wasn't that great.The pizza was great, if you've been to Franco Manca, it's very similar and I can't fault it at all. I just wish the staff had been more attentive as it ruined what could have been a much better experience. I wasn't aware that this place had hype until seeing a Reddit thread where people were gushing over it. I'd say it's worth a try, but I haven't been back since.

rX7VTxW22GvG18rvhazK6A.text: Unfortunately due to limited seating if you go during busy periods finding a place to seat is extremely hard however once you do find a seat and order food it is incredibly worth it. The pizza uses fresh ingredients and the base is thin. The staff are so nice sometimes their English is not that good but even besides the language barrier they are so helpful and really want you to have a good meal/experience, definitely one of my favourite pizzerias

bbATF11on8bScrrbqbx7BQ.text: After reading reviews for this place and hearing people go on about how great it was I thought it was about time I joined the  45 minutes average waiting list! Unfortunatley, I was left disappointed. Maybe it's been hyped up toooo much. The pizza is decent but I've had better elsewhere for much less. I had the Santa Caterina. The pizza I felt, was too soft/doughy in the middle. It had to be eaten with a knife and fork as holding it was impossible. Also, there was a bit too much crust - perhaps that's why the it was soggy in the middle as the toppings were all concetrated there. The flavours were all there, lovely tomato base Overall, it's a decent restaurant but I wouldn't travel all the way to Ealing for it when Pizza Pilgrim or Franco Manca are still around.

tZOrtDN7_FOrz-QoOmQ2FQ.text: Unfortunately, the Pizza was not that good. We had all ordered differently. One Calzone, a ham, rocket and tomato Pizza and one Ham, Artichoke and mushroom Pizza. Three strong choices.That is what we thought and hoped, but Santa Maria was not able to deliver on flavour and taste. Things just seemed to be missing. Seasoning was lacking from the Pizza; the urge you get of wanting to eat more and more was not there with our Pizzas. The bite and crunch of the base and dough was missing and although the base was nice and fluffy, it lacked that char and bite from a wood fired oven that we all wanted.The bad service and Pizza not really living up to current London standards meant this visit became more of a social thing rather than a foodie experience.It was a good start, a mediocre middle and the same with the ending; once again left waiting to leave and pay the bill. Put the customers first and I am sure the rest will sort itself out. I don't think I will be back to try this place. ​I do hope the Pizza is better in Naples.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Ham mushroom and artichoke pizza

Zvo1GSoP5wTCV8iyaFUHeg.text: Worst pizza I've ever had. Burnt and soggy. This place is too hyped. The pizza I had was a margarita, and don't ask me how one can mess up a margarita but apparently it's possible. It tasted burned bread and tomatoes with tons of salt. The service was bad as well and the pizza is overrated. I'd rather go to any other pizzeria than coming back here again

VY6wsaY65Ft9aBdiltGDDQ.text: Santa Maria is claimed by some to be the best pizza place in London. I'd say if it's not #1, then definitely in Top10 or in other words one of the best in Ealing for sure.The place itself is tiny with just 6 tables offering seating for 16 people altogether inside the restaurant and a couple of tables outside. It seems like there is a lot of staff as you  hear Italian quarrel while waiting for your pizza, but it just adds up to the authentic atmosphere. They do takeaway as well, that can justify the big crew of staff.I went for San Gennaro pizza with anchovies, black olives and capers and also tried my friend's Calzone San Salvatore with prosciutto, mozzarella and ricotta. Both were delicious and juicy with a good portion of tomato sauce spread across the thin dough. Definitely recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Better than Fanta :P
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Santa Maria Decor :)
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

b1sHDnoHQGiSAkJgwQXttg.text: I have been here a few times & really enjoyed it. The pizzas are delicious, authentic & lots of variety. It's a nice hidden little pizza gem in West London! The only 2 negatives I would have to say are that they do not do any bookings & therefore may be waiting a while for a table as it gets very busy. And last thing is that they do not have good quality wine.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

HnQL6dJLksh4nTmZEFLXUA.text: This should have been a better experience based on the reviews. It bills itself as authentic Neopolitan pizza, but sadly, does not come close to measuring up. It may be one of the best pizza restaurants in Ealing, but in a blind world, a one-eyed person is king. Waiting is too long. The restaurant makes no effort to move people off once they've finished eating. We waited 45 minutes and watched a precious table of 4 outside get served.  After our wait and dining -- another 40 min, the foursome was still seated as we left, despite the fact that there was still a line to get in. Management seemed to tolerate their inconsiderate lingering. Service is not very good. We ordered a salad to start, then two appetizers and one pizza.  The salad never came out. They forgot and apologized. The eggplant app was good, but the 4 meatballs were just ok, and they were the size of marbles. We specifically requested our pizza be baked well-done. What we received was not even close to cooked. It was very doughy, and the cheese was barely melted. So to net it out:  service & overall experience was not good.   Ambiance is crowded, hot and noisy. Food is so-so. Very undeserving of the rating it has.

_l11SW3iQ7u2uP-zYq0cRg.text: One of the best pizza places I ever been, great pizza, all fresh and great quality ingreadients.And the place just make you fill in Italy with a really friendly staffNot many tables so sometimes is worth getting as a take away or passing earlier to get your name on the list ( is worth the waiting)

md3z1dV82W_6bq78i8OLiA.text: WOW! I had been keeping my eye on this place through the refurbishment period and to definitely go before I left for the states...glad I did and I might go again!This little charm is perfect in every way...charming knowledgable Italian server, cute and cozy interior, good selection of wine, and the fresh, amazing, delicious pizzas! I had the San Mattia with truffle. Note that there is no red tomato sauce, but who cares!! It's as moist and fresh as it gets!Dessert, homemade Tiramisu of course and to really spruce up your espresso, have it with a scoop of vanilla ice cream in it, such a delight!For me, it's not just the food that makes a great dining experience, it's the whole atmosphere and here-you just feel like you are in Italy having divine food!PS- Be prepared to wait up to an hour, but don't let that deter you...go have some wine/beer at the pub next door to wet your appetite, DONE!

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. San Mattia truffle pizza. Mmmmm

pqOGMT8LIkYMMN72Ku1a7g.text: Was in Ealing for an event and decided to come here based on Yelp rating. Its a small restaurant which was very busy. Luckily we were only 2 and they had a room in the back with a couple of small tables free.Positives:+ Attentive and quite quick service+ Nice tasting pizzas of decent size+ Good value for moneyOn the down side:- I found the garlic focaccia a bit bland- My pizza base was pretty floppy - I was using cutlery to eat the pizza anyway, but not sure if I could have used hands to eat this if I wanted to- It was very very hot in the back room.Verdict: Overall very positive, will return if am in Ealing again, good pizza but didn't have my mind blown like I was expecting given the hype about the place.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

U4asanMys_fztdMpM02BbA.text: Time and again I have been here and every time I love it! Beautiful fresh pizza made with a pizza oven shipped over brick by brick from Napoli. The owners here are extremely proud of their pizza and so they should be. I love the quaintness of the restaurant as well. They could get a bigger place easily judging by the lines for a table outside the door every night but no they want to keep it small and intimate with just enough covers to make the atmosphere great!The only negative I a have is sometime the clientele to hang a little long on these tables. But hey that is the Italian way!Definitely one of the top 5 in London.

6GdufOsyLlKoYgiOmCrbaA.text: Rated by Timeout and London Evening Standard as "The Best Pizza in London", we figured we had to give this a try since we were in the area.  And we needed to know: whats all the buzz surrounding Neapolitan pizza?  Guess we just don't understand it.. wasn't for me :/  A few notes about Neapolitan pizza (for those who don't really know):- usually 1 size, roughly 12" - base is thin, and the crispy crust has layers of poofiness- served uncut- cooks in a wood oven in about 2 minutes- best enjoyed by eating in.  Take out will cool the pizza down quickly, steam within the box, and make it soggy- the center is usually a bit soggy / wet- basic / minimal toppings, with a balanced ratio of crust to toppings- toppings are kept simple: fresh mozzarella, basil, oregano, crushed tomatoes, salami.. pretty much back to basics (ie: not Americanized)We did do takeout b/c it was going to be a 45-min wait.. so we broke one of the cardinal rules!  The pizza definitely was cold after a 5 minute drive.  The pizza did meet all of the above rules, but maybe the cold pizza dampened the experience.  But I think even if it was hot, a Neapolitan pizza isn't for me.  Simple and delicious toppings, yes, but I really can't stand a soggy center, even if the outer crust is beautifully puffy and crispy.  We also ordered garlic bread, which wasn't garlicky at all.  I think they might have used garlic powder or a garlic-infused butter / oil for it.  But either way, it just tasted like salty oregano bread.On the plus side, the price is right for an entire pizza to feed one person, roughly £9.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom

PA2hIvyMPmrZFyMXxgBKww.text: That's More Like it. After an awful experience at another Ealing independent Pizza restaurant ( Pizza on the Green -http://www.yelp.co.uk/biz/pizza-on-the-green-london#query:Pizza%20On%20The%20Green) after not being able to get seated at Santa Maria last month - we made sure we got here early. Even for around 6.30/7pm on a Friday evening, this tiny (and I mean teeny-tiny) restaurant was very lively. It's certainly not a place you would come to for a quiet meal, but a place to come with a (small) group of friends.There were only two waiters, both classically Italian with the lingo, but without the attitude. They coped well, but were very preoccupied. The restaurant is full of rustic old boxes on the walls and hanging garlic and what not - but not too cluttered. Overall it is a very clean and relaxed atmosphere which was great. The Menu is simple. Pizzas, a few starters, good descriptions and there's lots of vegetarian choices. I say that - the V marked pizzas have Parmesan Cheese on them - when I asked if it was 'veggie Parmesan' they said no. So, watch out veggies. Also, if you assume all pizzas come with a tomato based sauce, then you're wrong. They're happy to put it on, but not all pizzas have the classic sauce. I ordered the pizza with courgettes and artichokes and mozzarella. They ingredients were of good quality and the dough was lush. Thin, but not sloppy or too moist.   Overall the flavors were very subtle which was great, but I prefer a more powerful taste. Still, a great classic pizza and a nice restaurant. I would give this place 3.5 stars. It is so small (and popular) it's hard to guess when a good time to go would be - and I'm not patient enough to wait. Plus, they do unfortunately lose an entire star for me for not having coke on the menu. I've never been anywhere where I couldn't get a coke with my meal and I was desperate for one (coca cola addict).I'm not saying it's the best pizza in London, but a must in Ealing.

photos.caption: Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Menu mmmm
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Santa Maria Pizzeria - London, United Kingdom. Francesco

boQJv9VqfeQ8POov6QXzYQ.text: Very friendly, Italian staff and the best pizzas I've ever eaten in London! Definitely recommended!

xTPHFqhV4A7baDVBwGC6sg.text: The hype for this place, is huge, so many people have praised this place and so, of course, it seemed like the right thing to try this place for myself.The restaurant is indeed, very small, bright with high ceilings and the kitchen in the same room lends a rustic, but modern feel. Nice enough.Service was good, quite alot of staff for such a small room though!We tried the bruschetta, which was good and highly disappointing at the same time: the bread was crunchy and garlicky, but slightly burnt, the tomatoes had boring oregano which did nothing and were blander than bland (good bruschetta does exist!)The pizza was good, soft, chewy, doughy crust, generous toppings, we all agreed there were alot of toppings for your money, just the way it should be. I had the San Mattia which was mushrooms, mountains of Parmesan and truffle oil on a white base. I got extra ham with it, which was thrown into the middle, I think if it was spread out, then it would have got abit crispy in the oven. I ate the lot, I think this is a good representation of a decent pizza from this side of Italy. Tiramisu was good, lots of layers, bit too much alcoholic sponge and not quite enough cream.Overall, I had a good time, would love to see more interesting pizza topping combos though. Worth 50% of the hype but I would love to go again.
